Compared with the convergence of MAML in centralized settingÂ Ji etÂ al. (2020),
TheoremÂ 4.3 has the same dependency on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon.
This also agrees with previous work on random-walk
algorithmsÂ Sun etÂ al. (2022); Triastcyn etÂ al. (2022),
though their analysis requires auxiliary parameters to be synchronized across all clients,
while AlgorithmÂ 2 uses localized ones.
The impact of communication network is reflected by the logâ¡(1/Ïƒ2â€‹(P))1subscriptğœ2ğ‘ƒ\log(1/\sigma_{2}(P)),
which also matches previous analysis on random-walk algorithmsÂ Sun etÂ al. (2022); Triastcyn etÂ al. (2022).
Then since LoDMeta has the same convergence rate (same number of iterations Tğ‘‡T)
but significantly smaller per-iteration communication cost CTsubscriptğ¶ğ‘‡C_{T} (as in TableÂ 1),
it has much smaller communication cost than existing methods.

Mini-ImageNet.
FigureÂ 1 compares the testing accuracies of training clients with communication cost for different methods.
We use the relative communication cost as in TableÂ 1.
Among random-walk methods, while LoDMeta(SGD) performs a bit worse,
LoDMeta(basic) and LoDMeta
achieve comparable performances with the centralized
learning methods (MAML and FedAlt),
and do not need additional central server to coordinate the learning process.
This agrees with TheoremÂ 4.3,
which shows AlgorithmÂ 2 has the same asymptotic convergence rate as centralized methods.
It also demonstrates the necessity of using adaptive optimizers for meta-learning problems.
Moreover, L2C has worse performance than reported in Li etÂ al. (2022a). This
may be due to that we use fewer
training samples and
smaller
number of neighbors, and
L2C overfits.222For the mini-ImageNet experiment,
Li etÂ al. (2022a)
use 500 samples for each client (50 samples per class), and each client has 10
neighbors. Here, we
use 100 samples for each client (20 samples per class), and the maximum number of neighbors is 5.
LoDMeta
is also more preferable than
LoDMeta(basic)
in the decentralized setting due to its smaller communication cost.

Meta-Datasets.
FigureÂ 3 compares the testing accuracies of training clients with communication cost for different methods and communication networks.
Within limited communication resources, LoDMeta achieves the best performances,
which comes from its significantly smaller per-iteration communication cost (1/3 of L2C/LoDMeta(basic) as in TableÂ 1).
Among all the baseline methods, L2C still has poorer performances than both centralized methods (MAML and FedAlt)
and random-walk methods (LoDMeta(SGD), LoDMeta(basic) and LoDMeta).

Effect of Random Perturbations for Privacy.
Since there are limited works on privacy protection for decentralized meta-learning,
here we study the performance of LoDMeta at different amounts of privacy perturbation,
which is controlled by the two hyper-parameters Ïµ,Î´italic-Ïµğ›¿\epsilon,\delta
used to generate the random perturbation Ïµtsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµğ‘¡\bm{\epsilon}_{t}.
TableÂ 2 (resp. TableÂ 3)
compares the testing accuracies on training (resp. unseen)
clients with different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and Î´ğ›¿\deltaâ€™s in AlgorithmÂ 2.
As is shown in TheoremÂ 4.5,
a larger perturbation (which corresponds to a smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon or Î´ğ›¿\delta)
leads to better privacy protection.
From both TablesÂ 2 and 3,
a smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon or Î´ğ›¿\delta leads to worse testing accuracies.
Hence, there is a trade-off between privacy protection and model performance,
which agrees with studies on other settingsÂ Hu etÂ al. (2020); Cyffers and Bellet (2022).

references:
Communication network.
For centralized methods (MAML and FedAlt),
the communication network is essentially a star,
with the server at the center.
For decentralized methods (L2C, LoDMeta(basic) and LoDMeta), we use two networks:
the popular Watts-Strogatz small-world network
Watts and Strogatz (1998), and
the 3-regular expander network, in which each client has 3 neighbors.
The number of clients for each data set is
in TableÂ 4 in AppendixÂ C.

Some statistics for data sets used in experiments are in TableÂ 4.
All data sets used in our experiments are released under Apache 2.0 license.
FigureÂ 5(a) gives an example for small-world network,
while FigureÂ 5(b) gives an example for 3-regular expander network.
These two network types are used in our experiments (with different number of clients).
